bubbles.text: What a tragic story…
He was my friend.
A fatherly figure.
That gentleman hired me as a language tutor for his daughters.
Daughters?
Never heard of 'em.
Two of them married, one betrothed to a noble.
My little Aphanasia…
That's odd…
When we were preparing to go…
I asked her father to let her leave with us.
What?
But we were both there!
You murdered that man in cold blood!
No, it was an accident!
We only meant to subdue him…
Just one of the necessary casualties of my mutiny.
Not at all! Alas…
He did not take my offer well.
He grabbed me by my neck and…
I had to choose between his death or mine.
There was no other way to take Aphanasia with us.
I did it for her sake, as well as sir Stepanov's.
His later betrayals were a result of his jealousy…
of the love that Aphanasia had for me.
I know nothing of such woman!
Lies! Complete fabrication!
Could there really have been someone like that?

incorrect_dialogue.text: Surely you don't think this proves anything?
Don't you think it's all a little off?

end_bubbles.text: Could there really indeed?
One would think that if lady Aphanasia really was there...
Mr Ryumin would have met her.
Why don't we look into this further?

stages.title: How many ladies were on board?

bubbles.text: Whatever do you mean?
We left with ninety-six people.
Nine of those people were women.
Eight wives…
and the governor's young daughter.
Now hang on a moment here!
The ship set sail with seventy people on board.
No more.
Out of those, I think there were four wives…
Oh, and our pilot Tchurin's two daughters.
I remember there being 70 people.
And a dog we found along the way…
But there were seven women total.
The wives of our navigator... Andreyanov... Tchurin...
Bocharov... Parantsin.... and me.
Oh, and Tchurin's daughter!
Weren't there two?

incorrect_dialogue.text: Let's focus on the matter at hand.

restart_dialogue.text: There's no way Aphanasia was aboard.

end_bubbles.text: Regardless how many daughters Tchurin had...
There is no way Aphanasia was on the ship!
Recognized by neither Ryumin nor Stepanov...
She's a complete fabrication!
Your excuse why Stepanov tried to sabotage you does not hold!

bubbles.text: What kind of question is that?
Of course it was me!
There was a vote!
I was unanimously elected captain!
As if!
Despite your best efforts to undermine me...
I was the commander on that ship!
What?
Then who left me stranded on that island?
Stranded?
I don't recall you being left stranded anywhere.
Or you being on my ship, for that matter.
Maybe you were one of my less significant crewmen?
Preposterous!
We all witnessed it happen!
None of us wanted to leave them stranded!
We begged the Captain...
But he didn't budge.
I had to make an example!
No one threatens mutiny on my ship!

end_bubbles.text: Stepanov, sir...
I'm afraid that's not possible.
We have a confirmation that the Baron was in charge.
You're attempting to claim his actions for yourself!
Which brings us to another question...

stages.title: Did the ship really go to America?

bubbles.text: Yes! A thousands times yes!
A storm blew us off-course, so I had no idea where I was.
Did you already forget?
We disposed of Izmaylov on the very island…
where Captain Bering lay buried!
The Bering Island! North-east of Kamchatka!
Or dare you claim that it was elsewhere?
Pfft, Bering Island?
You wouldn't be able to pinpoint your location...
even if it was written on a mountain!
It's true that I don't remember going eastward....
Marikan Island. That's where you left us to rot.
One of the Kurils, south of Kamchatka, you lying dog.
And how can you be so sure?
Because unlike you, I know how to use a compass!
I learned of those islands from the traders who saved me.
I wouldn't dare doubt them. Would you?
But why would our Captain lie about it?
I didn't. I never said we sailed east.
Enough with your false claims!

incorrect_dialogue.text: What are you trying to say?

restart_dialogue.text: I know darn well we didn't go east.

end_bubbles.text: I can think of only one reason!
Captain Benyovsky...
you lied about your location to claim to be a skilled explorer...
to hide that you were completely lost on the sea!
And that means that whever happened next was also a fabrication!

stages.title: Where did the ship sail next?

bubbles.text: I wasn't lost, I just kept our location a secret!
There are many people who would abuse that knowledge.
But it doesn't matter,
since we set course for Japan anyway.
I just remember a big storm....
Our ship tossed from side to side...
We were praying for safety.
Two of our masts broke.
There was no choice but to land there.
Luckily my navigational skill brought the ship to port safely.

incorrect_dialogue.text: That has nothing to do with this!

restart_dialogue.text: We were scared for our lives...

end_bubbles.text: You "set course for Japan"?
That doesn't sound right at all.
When the storm came,
even though you knew it would be a gamble of your own lives,
you still decided to arrive at those shores.

stages.title: What really went down by the Japanese shore?

bubbles.text: Accidental or not, the ship did land.
We were welcomed by a local king.
We were given food and water...
and I visited his palace.
There we talked...
and the king allowed me to return anytime.
All lies!
Nothing you said was true!
We tried to arrive to the shore...
but were rejected...
and led to a different port.
You know what happens to those who arrive outside Nangasaki.
Death to the crew...
and to anyone who let them in.
They allowed us to arrive at a port,
but when we tried to leave the ship,
we were ordered to stay.
They still brought us food and water...
but at no point did we take a step on the Japanese soil.
The locals must have received secret instructions...
because they later set up a trap.
We barely escaped with out lives.

incorrect_dialogue.text: I had no reason to lie.

restart_dialogue.text: We really were attacked, weren't we?

end_bubbles.text: I find your excursion difficult to believe.
You say you visited the king's palace...
even though the Japanese forbid you to leave the ship?
Isn't this another of your fancy fabrications?

stages.title: What proves Benyovsky's presence in Japan?

bubbles.text: I have proof!
I mean that the Dutch have it!
Once we departed, I prepared several letters.
They contained details of our visit.
I handed them over at our next stop.
The Dutch can attest I set foot on that island.
Letters... about Japan...
The Dutch don't have them.
The Japanese do.
A certain Hanbengoro really threw a spanner in the works.
Next year Russia will attack Japan from the north.
Ring a bell?
Thanks to your little adventure,
we Russians can no longer sail near Japan.
I have no idea what you're talking about.

incorrect_dialogue.text: That has nothing to do with me!

restart_dialogue.text: This is your one and only chance.

end_bubbles.text: Baron Benyovsky...
or should I say, "Hanbengoro",
in the name of Her Imperial Majesty,
you are under arrest
for the murder of governor Grigorii Nilov
as well as acts of terrorism
threatening relations between the nations of Russia and Japan.
